results.title: Memory packs
results.brief_description:
This CD-ROM was created with funding by the Commonwealth Government through the Australia council - its arts and funding advisory body, and by the City of Port Philip Cultural Development Fund.
The work is an interactive exhibition of objects that evoke stories or memories. Young people, old people, people from diverse backgrounds, artists, entertainers, the famous, the infamous and the not yet discovered - all were asked to contribute an object of personal significance and a story to accompany it. The CD-ROM has a linked website (www.experimenta.org/gallery/memorypacks/description.html).

results.title: Memory lingers on (Episode 4)
results.brief_description: Illustrates some of the latest research into the workings of the brain. Examines the memory capacity of the brain and probes such questions as “Does memory remain the same over the years?”, “How does memory influence everyday actions”, and “Is the script for the future already written - from memory?” Also gives details of how external stimuli are processed by the brain.

results.title: Memory
results.creator_credit: Robert Potter and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Memory is the connection between the past and present which shapes our personality and as such is of vital interest to psychologists. How does it work? This program outlines some of the approaches which have been taken to unlock its mystery, particularly in the fields of neurobiology and neurochemistry, and the study of amnesia and Alzheimer’s disease. If we can discover how memory works then maybe cures for these crippling conditions can be developed, not to mention the implications for educators.

results.title: Memory
results.brief_description:
“When an elephant lost his memory, a goldfish tried to help him to remember his past with her limited memory. The elephant couldn’t remember anything. He even forgot the goldfish. At last, the elephant just left everything behind and walked away.”
Slow-moving, visually provocative and backed by a haunting soundtrack,
this work has a surrealistic quality that engages the viewer. Its allegorical theme of memory is beautifully portrayed through a conversation between a man and a woman,and their relationship to one another. Filmed in black and white with English subtitles.

results.title: Memories of war: Australians in Vietnam. Part 2
results.brief_description: Three soldiers who served in the Vietnam War detail their experiences of training and combat. Max Nicolson describes his conscription through the “marble” system, and explains the importance of mateship during basic training. Alf Law discusses the racism directed towards the Vietnamese and his personal experiences of Agent Orange. Peter Harris discusses his hatred of army training and also the deep conflicts faced by the soldiers when they returned to Australia and confronted wide-spread opposition to their involvement in the War.

results.title: Memories of war: Australians in Vietnam. Part 1
results.brief_description: Interviews with three Australians who served in the Vietnam War. Kevin Freeman and John Dellaca served as conscripts in the war, and both talk of their combat experiences as well as their difficulties in returning to Australia. Fay Lewis served as a nurse in Vietnam and she discusses the pressures of being a female in the “male” environment of war, as well as explaining the experiences that led to her involvement in the anti-war movement. The interviews reveal the horror of war as well as documenting the tensions faced by the conscripts about Australia’s involvement in the War.

results.title: Memories of war
results.brief_description: Using vivid animation, the film examines the problem of war, its apparent necessity for creating jobs, protecting oil supplies, etc, and the climate of violence and insecurity which weighs heavily on the world. A haunting film rich with symbolism, this is a filmmaker’s please for a peaceful world in which to raise his newborn son. Using the menacing imagery of the howling wind, the artist evokes viewer to reflet on the insanity of war. While the film is symbolic, its message is unmistakably clear: unless there is an end to conflict, we will continue to see our children swept away like leaves in the wind.

results.title: Memorandum
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, John Spotton, John Kemeny and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The memorandum was Hitler’s and the subject was the final solution to the ‘Jewish problem’. In this outstanding documentary, a Jewish Canadian takes a holiday from his glazier’s shop in Toronto to join an emotional pilgrimage with 30 Jewish Americans to the necropolis of Bergen Belsen. In travelling through the New Germany, this man remembers - scenes still vivid in his mind are recalled in flashback. Includes footage of concentration camp administrators on trial for their role in the Holocaust. (Awards: San Francisco, Venice, Vancouver, Montreal)

results.title: Memo...Melbourne...Australia
results.creator_credit: Bilcock and Copping Film Productions and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A brief, non-narrated look at Melbourne, using facts and statistics to give an outline of industry and manufacture, transport, energy resources, people and government. Commissioned by the Victorian Film Corporation on behalf of State Development.
